results.title: Botanic man
results.brief_description: An amazing 10-part series, tracing the evolution and adaptation of life on earth. The programs take a botanical point of view because it is the plants that form the basis of the energy web which enables life as we know it to exist in this world.

results.title: Crackpot, jackpot: Human contrasts and survival
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Botanic man”.
This program takes a look at the problems caused by the high energy consumption of modern countries and some possible solutions. It contrasts life in California, the inhabitants of a tower block who live in a completely controlled environment and the inhabitants of Mexico where Indians are farming land which is rich in oil and great changes are about to embrace them.

results.title: Life on the limit: cultivation and the environment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Botanic man”.
Highlights the problems caused by the development of agriculture, focusing on India with the agricultural revolution in Assam which caused one of the first man-made ecological disasters. As the trees were felled to make way for cultivation, the soil was unprotected and the vital minerals were eroded from the soil by the heavy rainfall. It is an example of a paradox that has plagued almost every one of the developments modern man has achieved.

results.title: Greenprint for life
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Botanic man”.
Botanist and ecologist, David Bellamy, takes us deep into the Amazonian jungle to illustrate the complex ecosystems which have evolved there. The Indians, animals and plants exist in harmony, each dependent on the other in cycles of growth, decay and regrowth. Bellamy stresses the importance of this balance between man and nature and explains the adaptations plants have made in this hot, wet, dense environment to maximise photosynthesis, the by-product of which is the all important oxygen on which our world relies.

results.title: Demons and deities
results.creator_credit: John Darling, John McLean and Bozado
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Bali triptych”.
Balinese religion is an amalgam of the worship of local deities and Hindu and Buddhist beliefs. The Balinese display a strong sense of community co-operation and collective responsibility in their adherence to ancestor worship. This is most apparent in the regularity of their attendance at complex rituals at numerous temples and shrines across the island. This program records and explains the significance of many of the most important ceremonies of the 210 day Balinese calendar, ceremonies which feature sacred dance, frenzied trance states and mass exorcism, animal sacrifice, cock fighting, mock battles and time-consuming preparation of elaborate and beautiful decorations and offerings of food.

results.title: The Path of the soul
results.creator_credit: John Darling, John McLean and Bozado
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Bali triptych”.
This second part of a fascinating trilogy on the history, culture and way of life of the people of Bali concentrates on the spiritual beliefs of the Balinese. The Balinese believe in the fundamental unity of all aspects of existence, from birth, to death, to rebirth. Religion is practised as an integral part of daily life and has survived the absorption of Bali into the greater nation of Indonesia and a flood of western tourists. The complex and colourful purification and consecration rites for marriage, pregnancy, birth and death, shown in the video are still practised to maintain the balance between man, nature and the spiritual world and to offer protection from evil spirits.

results.title: Between the mountain and the sea
results.creator_credit: John Daling, John McLean and Bozado
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Bali triptych”.
The first part of a fascinating trilogy on the history, culture and way of life of the people of Bali provides an extensive historical survey of the island. Commencing with the myths and legends of pre-history, the program progresses through the peaceful adoption of Buddhism and then Hinduism by the Balinese, the Javanese conquest of Bali in 1343 which led to an unprecedented flowering of Balinese art and literature, the Dutch annexation of Bali in the mid-19th century which the Balinese met with fierce resistance and mass suicides, the Japanese invasion in 1942 and finally the tourist invasion which still goes on today. The program also covers the Balinese rice industry and the importance of dramatic art in conveying Bali’s history to the Balinese.

results.title: The Pacific century
results.creator_credit: Alex Gibney, Teleac Holland, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Nihon Hoso Kyokai, Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description: A series which describes and explains the emergence, from the nineteenth century onward, of modern nations from the rich and varied cultures and societies of Pacific Asia. A Study Guide and Faculty Manual are also available to accompany this telecourse.

results.title: The Pacific century
results.creator_credit: Marc Levin, Al Levin, Teleac Holland, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.), Jigsaw Productions and PBI Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The Pacific century”.
The final program in the series looks at America’s future as a “Pacific nation” by charting current economic and political trends, including the flood of Asian investment in the U.S., the domination of Asian technology and the rapid growth of Asian immigration. Through portraits of politicians, business leaders and working men and women “The Pacific century” will confront the economic, political and cultural challenges that will determine America’s future in this region to which it is inextricably connected.
